facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 52/X of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 381 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 52/X of 1954.

facts.text: The appellant is a private limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a private limited companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, and is carrying on business as marine engineers and ship repairers.

facts.text: Appellant's registered office is in Bombay and it is resident and ordinarily resident in India.

anchor.surface_text: Its registered office is in Bombay and it is resident and ordinarily resident in India.

facts.text: Appellant's entire share capital is beneficially owned by two British companies, the P. O. Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Its entire share capital is beneficially owned by two British companypanies, the P. 0. Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co. Ltd., whose business companysists in plying ships for hire.

facts.text: The two British companies' business consists in plying ships for hire.

anchor.surface_text: whose business companysists in plying ships for hire.

facts.text: Under an agreement with the two non-resident companies, the appellant repairs their ships at cost, and charges no profits.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement entered into with the two companypanies aforesaid, which will be referred to hereinafter as the number-resident companypanies the appellant repairs their ships at companyt, and charges numberprofits.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer took the view that appellant arranged business with non-resident companies so as to produce no profits due to close connection.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Bombay who dealt with the matter took the view that the appellant companypany had so arranged its business with the number-resident companypanies that it did number produce any profits to it, and that was because it was those companypanies that really owned its share capital,

facts.text: ITO computed profits under s.42(2) at Rs. 6,80,000 for account year 1943-1944.

anchor.surface_text: and that therefore the profits which it companyld ordinarily have made but for their close financial companynection were liable to be taxed under s. 42 2 , and he companyputed the same at Rs. 6,80,000 for the account year 1943-1944,

facts.text: ITO computed profits at Rs. 4,67,559 for account year 1944-1945.

anchor.surface_text: at Rs. 4,67,559 for the account year 1944-1945 and at Rs. 4,68,963 for the account year 1945-46.

facts.text: ITO computed profits at Rs. 4,68,963 for account year 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: at Rs. 4,68,963 for the account year 1945-46. On the basis of the above findings, orders of assessment of income-tax were made for the account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946

facts.text: Orders of assessment made for income-tax for 1944-45 and 1945-46 and excess profits tax for 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the above findings, orders of assessment of income-tax were made for the account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946 and of excess profits tax for the account years 1943-1944, 1944-1945 and 1945-1946.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who confirmed by order dated July 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Against these five orders, the appellant preferred appeals to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who by his order dated July 3, 1952, companyfirmed the same.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Tribunal; Bench divided, President by order dated March 19, 1954 held s.42(2) inapplicable and set aside assessments.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was a further appeal by the appellant to the Appellate Tribunal, and the Bench which heard the same having been divided in its opinion, the matters came up for hearing before the President, who by his order dated March 19, 1954, held that s. 42 2  was inapplicable and he accordingly set aside the orders of assessment

facts.text: On Department's application, Tribunal referred question: Whether on the facts and circumstances any income falls to be included in appellant's assessment under s.42(2).

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question for the opinion of the High Court of Bombay Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case any income falls to be included in the appellants assessment under s. 42 2 .

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ and Tendolkar J) by judgment dated February 24, 1955 held s.42(2) applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Chagla C. J. and Tendolkar J. who by their judgment dated February 24, 1955, held that, on the facts found, s. 42 2  was applicable and that the appellant was liable to be assessed

facts.text: Appellant obtained leave to appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied for and obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: On December 31, 1948, assessment order made for 1943-44 without including s.42(2) profits.

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned that on December 31, 1948, an order of assessment bad been made in respect of the income-tax payable by the appellant for the account year 1943-1944, and therein, the profits chargeable under s. 42 2  had number been included.

facts.text: ITO took action under s.34 and on May 29, 1953 made order assessing appellant for 1943-44 under s.42(2); appeal pending before AAC.

anchor.surface_text: But subsequently, the Income-tax Officer took action under s. 34 of the Act, and on May 29, 1953, made an order assessing the appellant to tax for that year on the profits deemed to have been made by it under s. 42 2 , and against that order, an appeal is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Present proceedings concern only assessments for income-tax 1944-45 and 1945-46 and excess profits tax 1943-44 to 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: That order is number the subject-matter of the present proceedings, which are companycerned only with the assessment of income-tax for the account years 1944-1945 and 1945-1946 and of excess profits tax for the account years 1943-1944, 1944-1945 and 1945- 1946.

facts.text: Non-resident companies send ships for repair to appellant under special agreement at cost.

anchor.surface_text: The number-resident companypanies send their ships for repair to the appellant, number as they might to any other repairer but under a special agreement that repairs should be done at companyt.

facts.text: Non-resident companies get ships repaired for use in their business of plying ships.

anchor.surface_text: And further unlike customers who purchase goods for their own companysumption or use, the number-resident companypanies get their ships repaired for use in what is admittedly their business.

facts.text: Court holds that non-resident companies carried on business with appellant within s.42(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .

That sub-section runs as follows Where a person number resident or number ordinarily resident in the taxable territories carries on business with a person resident in the taxable territories, and it appears to the Income-tax Officer that owing to the close companynection between such persons the companyrse of business is so arranged that the business done by the resident person with the person number resident or number ordinarily resident produces to the resident either DO profits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that business, the profits derived therefrom, or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom, shall be chargeable to income-tax in the name of the resident person who shall be deemed to be, for all the purposes of this Act, the assessee in respect of such income tax.

concepts.interpretation: The section taxes the business of the resident, not the non-resident, where due to close connection, the resident makes no or less than ordinary profits.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, on the construction contended for by the appellant s. 42(2) would become practically useless because a non-resident whose profits could be taxed under s. 42(2) could also be taxed under s. 42(1), as also the resident if he were the agent.

holdings.text: The language of s.42(2) plainly imposes the charge on the profits derived from or deemed to have been derived from the business done by the resident with the non-resident, and the business that is the subject of the charge is that of the resident and not of the non-resident.

anchor.surface_text: The word therefrom is very important for the purpose of the present discussion. In the context, it can refer only to the business of the resident, and it is this business therefore that is the subject of the charge under s. 42 2 It was suggested for the appellant that the word therefrom has reference to the arrangement between the numberresident and the resident, but apart from the fact that such a construction would, on the grammar of it, be untenable, it is impossible to conceive how an arrangement relating to the course of business can, as such, be the subject-matter of income-tax, apart from the business in which profits or gains are made. The language of the section is clear beyond all reasonable doubt as to what it is that is sought to be taxed under this section. That is only the business of the resident and number that of the numberresident.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of 'therefrom' refers to resident's business described earlier; associated with 'deemed profits' due to no/low profits to resident; rejects petitioner's textual and harmonious arguments.

holdings.text: The words 'profits derived therefrom, or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived therefrom' refer to the resident's business, with 'derived' for cases of low profits and 'deemed' for no profits.

anchor.surface_text: It is on the expression profits derived in the charging part of the enactment that the appellant leans heavily in support of his position that it is the business of the number- resident that is really intended to be taxed. But then, those words do number stand alone. They are associated with the words or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived , and this association has its origin in the preceding clause produces to the resident either numberprofits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that business . This clause contemplates two classes of cases, one where the business of the resident produces numberprofits and the other where it produces less than the normal profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading links to clause about profits/no profits 'to the resident'; 'or' read as 'and' to avoid absurdity.

holdings.text: Rules 33 and 34 do not support the view that s.42(2) taxes the non-resident's profits or require apportionment of non-resident's world profits; they do not alter the plain meaning of the section.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 33 provides for the determination of the profits of a number- resident in cases falling within s. 42 1 , and one of the modes prescribed for such determination is to fix an amount which bears the same proportion to the total profits of the number-resident as the Indian receipts bear to the total receipts in the business. Rule 34 then provides that the profits derived from any business carried on in the manner referred to in s. 42  2  may be determined for the purposes of assessment to income-tax according to the preceding rule . Now, the argument of Mr. Palkhivala is that the interpretation put on s. 42  2  by the rule-making authorities as manifest in R. 34 is that the business chargeable under s. 42  2  is that of the number-resident,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules framed under s.42(1) applied by reference in 34; no indication they interpret s.42(2) as taxing non-resident; rules cannot override statute.

holdings.text: The provisions making profits chargeable 'in the name of the resident' and deeming the resident the assessee explain the taxation of deemed (fictional) profits of the resident's business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also relied on the clauses in s. 42  2  that the profits shall be chargeable to tax in the name of the resident and that he shall be deemed to be the assessee for all purposes of the Act as indicating that it is number the business of the resident that is really sought to be taxed. But these clauses are explainable with reference to the fact that the profits taxed are number actual profits but what are deemed to be profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal fiction needed because profits are deemed, not actual; no need for fiction if taxing actual profits of resident.

holdings.text: The non-resident companies carried on business with the appellant within the meaning of s.42(2), as their ship repair activities under the special cost agreement constitute organised, continuous trading activities related to their business.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad fiscal meaning of 'business'; special agreement and use in non-residents' plying business create continuity akin to 'business connection' under s.42(1); cites precedents.

holdings.text: On the facts and circumstances, income falls to be included in the appellant's assessment under s.42(2), and the appellant is chargeable to tax thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: 1946. Now, the sole point for determination in this appeal is whether on the facts found the appellant is chargeable to tax under s. 42  2  of the Act. ... We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both conditions satisfied: close connection leading to no profits; non-residents carried on business with resident; rejects petitioner's grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Discussing the connotation of the word trade, Scott L. J. observed in Smith Barry V. Cordy 1 The history of judicial decisions has been similar, showing a strong tendency not to restrict the scope of Schedule D a tendency which was, we think, in sympathy with the general social and economic outlook of the country.

precedents.cited_proposition: broad construction of the word 'trade' or 'business' in fiscal statutes
precedents.cited_holding: tendency not to restrict the scope of Schedule D; almost any activity for livelihood swept into fiscal net

precedents.citation: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. The Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax 2

anchor.surface_text: The word business connotes, it was observed by this Court in Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. The Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax 2 , some real, substantial and systematic or organised course of activity or conduct with a set purpose.

precedents.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents.cited_holding: 'business' connotes some real, substantial and systematic or organised course of activity or conduct with a set purpose

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Curimbhoy Ebrahim Sons 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax Curimbhoy Ebrahim Sons 1 , it was observed by the Privy Council that business connection in s. 42 1 is different from business as defined in s. 4 2 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Curimbhoy Ebrahim & Sons
precedents.cited_holding: 'business connection' is different from, though not unrelated to, the word 'business' defined in the Act

anchor.surface_text: And in Anglo-French Textile Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 , this Court has observed that when there is a continuity of business relationship between the person in British India who helps to make-the profits and the person outside British India who receives or realises his profits, such relationship does constitute a business connection.

precedents.case_name: Anglo-French Textile Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_holding: continuity of business relationship between person in India helping to make profits and person outside receiving them constitutes business connection

anchor.surface_text: The word therefrom is very important for the purpose of the present discussion. In the context, it can refer only to the business of the resident, and it is this business therefore that is the subject of the charge under s. 42 2 It was suggested for the appellant that the word therefrom has reference to the arrangement between the numberresident and the resident, but apart from the fact that such a construction would, on the grammar of it, be untenable, it is impossible to conceive how an arrangement relating to the course of business can, as such, be the subject-matter of income-tax, apart from the business in which profits or gains are made. The language of the section is clear beyond all reasonable doubt as to what it is that is sought to be taxed under this section. That is only the business of the resident and number that of the numberresident.
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: It is on the expression profits derived in the charging part of the enactment that the appellant leans heavily in support of his position that it is the business of the number- resident that is really intended to be taxed. But then, those words do number stand alone. They are associated with the words or which may reasonably be deemed to have been derived , and this association has its origin in the preceding clause produces to the resident either numberprofits or less than the ordinary profits which might be expected to arise in that business . This clause contemplates two classes of cases, one where the business of the resident produces numberprofits and the other where it produces less than the normal profits.
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also relied on the clauses in s. 42  2  that the profits shall be chargeable to tax in the name of the resident and that he shall be deemed to be the assessee for all purposes of the Act as indicating that it is number the business of the resident that is really sought to be taxed. But these clauses are explainable with reference to the fact that the profits taxed are number actual profits but what are deemed to be profits.
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.

edges.explanation: The holding directly and affirmatively answers the issue by stating that income falls to be included in the appellant's assessment under s.42(2), matching the question posed in the issue.

anchor.surface_text: 1946. Now, the sole point for determination in this appeal is whether on the facts found the appellant is chargeable to tax under s. 42  2  of the Act. ... We are accordingly of opinion that, on the facts found, the number-resident Companies must be held to have carried on business with the appellant as provided in s. 42 2 .
That is the view taken by the learned Judges in the Court below, and we are in agreement with it.
